com.samsung.sami.manifest.fields

Class Field

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.samsung.sami.manifest.fields.Field

  • public final class Field
extends Object
    A field is a java representation of a message property as viewed by a manifest program. A field must have a field descriptor (FieldDescriptor, which gives the field a standard name and a unit if required. Try and use the standard field descriptors defined in StandardFields and standard units defined in SI, NonSI and StandardUnits.

    Sami relies on the javax.measure interfaces for units and JScience for converter. See JScience for details and JScience documentation.

    If you need a unit that is not available you can define your own units. For example: 

        // Beats per minute
   Unit BEATS = new BaseUnit<>("b");
   Unit BEATS_PER_MINUTE = BEATS.divide(MINUTE);

   // Nutritionists calories
   Unit KILO_CALORIE = SI.JOULE.times(4.184);

    Similarly, if you need a field descriptor that is not standard you can define your own field descriptors. Note that if you just want to name a field with a name different from the one in the standard field (e.g. you want a field that's called surfaceTemp, you can use the FieldDescriptor.alias(String) method. (e.g. FieldDescriptor SURFACE_TEMPERATURE = TEMPERATURE.alias("surfaceTemp");).

    If you just want a field with a different value class, you can use the FieldDescriptor.alias(Class) method.

    A Field value can be expressed in a unit that is different from the one defined in the field descriptor, as long as both are representing the same measure (e.g. feet vs. meters, pounds vs. kilograms, etc.). In that case the system will do its best attempt at converting the value into the standard unit as defined by the field descriptor. This means that the value must be a numeric value, i.e. Double or Integer. When a value is an Integer and the conversion yields a double value, the value is rounded down to the nearest Integer value.

    For field descriptors that have no units use StandardUnits.NONE or no unit at all.

    Finally, a field must have a value if it is not a structure. This value must be of the same class defined in the field descriptor or a runtime exception will be thrown. However, If the field descriptor is a structure, then it must not have a value but have children fields instead. The fields must match the field descriptor structure.

    See Also:
    FieldDescriptor, StandardFields, StandardUnits, Unit, SI, NonSI
